I never suggested he wasn't dangerous. He stabbed people, cops knew that, I understand it was a tense situation. I don't know what you're envisioning, but this was not a case where the kid had a knife to a hostage's neck or something. The only people left to hurt were police -- humans and a dog. Considering they outnumbered a 15-year-old suspect clearly out of his mind and armed only with a knife, it seems like they could balance the need to "stop other people from getting stabbed" with the basic human desire, one presumes, not to kill a kid who has done terrible things during a mental break.
Instead of reflexively defending the officer's action, which again I agree was lawful, why don't we consider how a tragedy like this can be used as a teachable moment to avoid unnecessary loss of life.

How about a big weighted net...
I'm kidding, but honestly it seems like the non-lethal weapons and de-escalation tactics we give our police are lacking. We can do better.

They had time to use non-lethal force six times. And they are educated/licensed to kill people with ease. Why can't we all agree that we should shift some priorities away from killing and toward de-escalation, proper tactical confrontation, dealing with people in crisis, etc. to minimize the need to kill. Not saying they shouldn't be able to kill -- I agree that this case will be closed relatively quickly -- but we should all want to avoid seeing sad shit like this happen.
Taking hallucinogens can trigger a mental crisis though. Believe you me.

Officer can't be blamed for operating according to rules. Real question is whether cops should have more options for dealing with someone in a mental crisis. Not just a matter of non-lethal weapons, though it seems like there are probably more devices out there that could shut down a situation like this, beyond what they had. But maybe serious psych help from a professional would actually work better than deciding that the proper way to respond to a violent incident is with further violence.

Anyway, jailing people for poverty doesn't make sense. I'm sure a lot of these fines could simply be forgiven without massive damage to the systems that have come to accept massive arbitrary fines as the cost of business. A little bit on Australia and what the nation actually did after Port Arthur. They held a mandatory buyback of banned weapons types and destroyed automatic and semi-automatic rifles and shotguns. This was not the kind of "confiscation" many people try to scare us with today. Brown-shirts did not go door to door grabbing guns. And while they did raise the bar for gun ownership and create a registry, there are still plenty of guns in Australia today.
http://www.abc.net.au/news/2016-04-28/alpers-the-truth-about-gun-ownership-after-port-arthur/7365790

Depends on your definition of "better." They could make an intruder more dead than a pistol could. They could also fill your house and your neighbor's house full of stray bullets. I don't think anyone *needs* an AR-15 for home defense. A shotgun has always seemed like a more sensible choice. But I can see why gun-lovers want them. I can also see why making them available to civilians poses and inherent, though infrequent, risk.

No person who has a remote grasp of this issue, politician or otherwise, thinks we're ever going to get rid of civilian gun ownership. Even those who wish we lived in a utopia where people didn't ever need firearms understand that it would be impossible, both politically and logistically, to get rid of 400 million civilian-owned firearms. Once we get this conspiratorial distraction out of the way, we can have an open discussion about whether the proposals we're seeing now are actually effective or worthwhile. If they're not, it's because the proposals are shitty, not because it's impossible to find an acceptable middle ground that will address gun violence and satisfy legal gun owners.

Not true. Assault-style rifles are better tools, plain and simple. Easier to shoot, better accuracy, better range, are in most cases capable of carrying significantly more ammunition, have higher muzzle velocity, less recoil, highly moddable, the list goes on. WRITING.TEXT: I think she's speaking to the motivation to force the motto upon people. That motivation harkens back to the Cold War and fear of communism. But yes, as a question of semantics, you are correct.

The biggest institutional push [came at the height of the Red Scare](https://www.treasury.gov/about/education/Pages/in-god-we-trust.aspx):
A law passed by the 84th Congress (P.L. 84-140) and approved by the President on July 30, 1956, the President approved a Joint Resolution of the 84th Congress, declaring IN GOD WE TRUST the national motto of the United States. IN GOD WE TRUST was first used on paper money in 1957, when it appeared on the one-dollar silver certificate. The first paper currency bearing the motto entered circulation on October 1, 1957. The Bureau of Engraving and Printing (BEP) was converting to the dry intaglio printing process. During this conversion, it gradually included IN GOD WE TRUST in the back design of all classes and denominations of currency.

WRITING.TEXT:
I'm aware that the union is just doing its job. I'm suggesting that the job is the problem. It leads to many bad officers -- but perhaps not criminally bad ones, at least according to the laws that favor them -- keeping their jobs. He was "fired," though that firing is now being challenged, which is why many officers in these cases are instead forced to resign.
You're also right that unions are not literally magic -- they can't force departments to continue employing a cop who is in jail for murder, for example. But I still think they do far more harm by protecting bad officers than they do by defending good ones who have legitimate gripes. In an ideal world, they could to the latter without doing the former.

This story demonstrates that even in the rare case a police department wants to fire an officer for messing up badly, they can't because of police unions. That's an old story. But the news here is that it holds true even when it's a high-profile case in which an officer has seemingly killed someone unnecessarily -- though whether it was illegal or not is yet to be determined. In my opinion, if a department believes an officer is no longer fit for their department, they shouldn't be forced to continue employing them due to a fucked up bureaucratic system that shelters cops who aren't good at their jobs.
